author: TheWizardOfFrobozz
body:
In the example you gave, there are two taxable events, both of which should be reported to the IRS:

1) Receiving the free stock. This counts are ordinary income for the market value of the stock on the day you receive it.
2) Selling the stock for a profit. This counts as a short-term or long-term capital gain (depending on how long you held it) of the amount its price increased by.

For example, suppose you received a free share of AAPL on July 30, 2019. AAPL closed at $213.04 that day, so you would report $213.04 as income. Now suppose you sold it on December 31, 2019 for $291.52. Your short-term capital gain is $291.52 - $213.04 = $78.48. Whether either of these events increases the taxes you have to pay depends on your other income, your filing status, other gains/losses, etc.

I'm thinking of writing a tax primer for Robinhood users and posting it here sometime during the next few days since there seem to be so many questions.

author: InfiniteAccuracy
body: Don't even ask the question. The answer is yes, it's priced in. Think Amazon will beat the next earnings? That's already been priced in. World War III? Priced in. You work at the drive thru for Mickey D's and found out that the burgers are made of human meat? Priced in. You think insiders don't already know that? The market is an all powerful, all encompassing being that knows the very inner workings of your subconscious before you were even born. Your very existence was priced in decades ago when the market was valuing Standard Oil's expected future earnings based on population growth that would lead to your birth, what age you would get a car, how many times you would drive your car every week, how many times you take the bus/train, etc. Anything you can think of has already been priced in, even the things you aren't thinking of. You have no original thoughts. Your consciousness is just an illusion, a product of the omniscent market. Free will is a myth. The market sees all, knows all and will be there from the beginning of time until the end of the universe (the market has already priced in the heat death of the universe). So please, before you make a post on wsb asking whether AAPL has priced in earpods 11 sales or whatever, know that it has already been priced in and don't ask such a dumb fucking question again.

author: return_to_the_void
body:
This is my answer too. I did really well on picks I made during the 2008/9 recession. I had a screener set up to show me stocks that reached an all-time high in 2007 and dropped a lot through 2008 and going into 2009. I also filtered on market cap to avoid penny stocks, and a few other factors.

With the list I had, I did some research on each and tried to guess which would continue their growth during a recovery. I was focused on growth, but I know plenty of other people who were picking up dividend growth stocks on a steep discount.

My best two picks were AAPL and ISRG.

The strategy I used wouldn't have worked well during the dotcom bubble burst because many of those companies never recovered or took ~10 years to eventually recover. But because the recession was due to factors unrelated to overvalued tech (the housing bubble), I felt confident investing in tech stocks and it paid of *really fucking well* for me.

author: dolpherx
body:
tech is actually not one basket. The term "tech" is very misleading as we are at just the beginning of a way of doing business using "tech". Each tech company actually operates in a different industry for example, Apple is in consumer products, Amazon is in retail and cloud computing, Facebook is in Social Media and Advertising, Google is in Advertising, Netflix is in Content Media and Media Distribution, Microsoft is in work productivity software and cloud computing, Nvidia is in semiconductors, Uber in transportation, and the list goes on.

Eventually there will be new categories and there will be a reshuffle of the companies into the new categories. This has already started a couple of years ago and will continue to do so until basically all of the old companies that used to be in those categories are forgotten like old railroad companies and the new categories will be based of the new technology. Currently everything is grouped up in tech. If you think tech is just one basket then you will miss the boat as you will be trying to diversify too much and invest in old companies which the tech companies are about to turn obsolete. Sure some old companies will survive, but history has shown that companies come and go like empires.

author: knotswag
body:
**Magical Crayons TA.**

[As I was saying yesterday](https://www.reddit.com/r/wallstreetbets/comments/euueg4/what_are_your_moves_tomorrow_january_28/ffrtwgr/), indicators were at oversold because we never had a reaction at the support level. I also said that normally it would have been a good place to buy the dip, but buying didn't come. I ascribed it to impending volatility and that waiting seemed wise. 

Today we did reverse up, and did so in a way that looked almost like a "delayed" reaction at the crayon support levels I had drawn, [gapping up almost precisely to the support and fighting up on the 5 minute chart.](https://imgur.com/7883OJk) 

With AAPL beating and futures mooning, I normally would be saying this is continued business as usual, even with some impending volatility ahead. But while we often joke about needing to feel the market around here, I really do have an uncomfortable feeling about this market behavior.  So for this Magical Crayons TA episode I will withhold any of my own ranges or predictions. For those that still want numbers, Bollinger Bands gives ranges at approximately 322.7-330.2. I think the earnings release of multiple big companies tomorrow AH and the FOMC meeting in the morning will provide better guidance from my own crayons. 

I hope you all grow lots of tendies tomorrow and let's see what Papa Powell does to the market.

author: MaxAds1
body:
AAPL Earnings Call Recap and what it means

Tim approaches you as you are sitting alone at a cocktail bar. You can’t help but notice how smooth he is - it’s almost like he’s floating above the ground.

He says something about numbers but you have no idea what it means, you’re just lost in his smooth voice. Before you know it you’re at his apartment, cuddled up on his beautiful leather sofa. 

He says to you, “Let’s take this to the next level.” 

You reply nervously, “I’m not so sure Tim, will it hurt?” 

He confidently replies, “I’m not sure, you tell me.”

It’s at this moment you notice he’s been inside you for over an hour. You tell him it’s your first time as he whispers, “Don’t worry, your tendies are safe with me.”

TLDR AAPL to 335 by EOW
RIP to the poor soul who bought my puts

author: 4d39faaf-80c4-43b5
body:
The article does mention AMZN, as a 'big 5' of tech - pointing out that Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet, Amazon, and Facebook are nearly 18% of the value of the SP500 right now.

However, the top 3, AAPL, MSFT, and GOOGL are somewhat unique, in that they all now have >1T$ market caps,  and somewhat grounded P/E ratios ( you have to admit AMZN's is a little wacky).

The other very notable thing about the big three is the BUYBACKS - we've recently seen TENS OF BILLIONS of dollars in buybacks from GOOGL, MSFT, AND APPL - these aren't debt-financed buybacks, but rather these companies cashflows are so insane they're paying dividends AND buying back billions of dollars in shares; AMZN is doing neither.

I'm not hating on AMZN by any means, I owns some shares, but I think this article argues, and I agree, that APPL, MSFT, GOOGL are in a 'tech blue chip' class which is all their own.

author: doougle
body:
I wish I had started counting when I started urging people **not to use stop orders with options**.  I bet I've typed those words 200 times now.

By default, it's the mark price that triggers the stop.  I'm not 100% sure RH does it this way too for most brokers, they use the midpoint between bid and ask to mark the price.  This works fine for a stock that normally has a bid/ask a few cents apart.  With an option, even something more liquid like AAPL, the spread can be a dollar or more wide.   So if the bid price drops to an unrealistic number, the platform just adjusts the midpoint, even if no one would ever sell for that price.   So now, with no real trade even happening, your trigger is hit and a market order to sell goes in to the market.  I see you used a stop limit.  That's only a little better than a stop because what do you set the limit to?

author: dingledicker
body:
ok hear me out u retards. what if options were actually supposed to be used as a hedge and not a way to gamble your money? and the large purchases of options you see are made by funds to hedge and not gamble. ok following me so far? those unusual call option activities you saw leading up to the 3rd of January, especially Jan. 2nd, were hedges, not gambles. what does this mean? it means large funds were already in the process of buying preemptive hedges in order to short stocks. remember those large amounts of 300/305/310 AAPL calls, and 50/51/52 AMD calls? those were hedges in preparation for a massive short movement in AAPL and AMD. those werent gambles in hopes the stocks would move up, which it could, but then they'd just profit. those call options were preemptive hedges to start shorting these stocks. the massive spike up during the last hour of trading on Jan. 2nd wasnt random. It might've been funds trying to buy the stock because there was a large request to short it, so they bought it so they could lend it out. now this shit may sound like a bunch of baloney, but i would bet that we do not see any recovery soon until mid jan at the earliest. there is no positive news until then which they could release to pump the market. china trade deal is set, and can only backfire if china backs out, the positives are already priced in. earnings doesnt start till mid-late january, so stocks will continue sliding down until then

(im buying puts and GLD btw, if im wrong u can thank me for saving ur calls)

author: pkincy
body: The definition of Irrational Exuberance is that it is irrational.  There is no "getting it."   It is insane.  Apple doubling over the past year with no to little profit increase is another.  Am I the only one to remember 1999?  From Mar of 99 to Mar of 2000 the NASDAQ doubled for no good reason.  This is exactly what this feels like.    By 2003 we all had egg on our faces and realized how really stupid we had been.  The NASDAQ had come down from near 5000 in Aug of 2000 to 1320 in Sept of 2002 and valuations were again reasonable.   And we got some progress forward from that point with rational exuberance.  What does interest me most is that doubling occurred the last time the Fed injected huge amounts of liquidity into the system, that time for the worry around computers and the date change from 99 to 00.   Then in late winter 2000 they started unwinding that trade and you saw the result.  Will that happen again this late winter or spring?   It sure feels possible.   TSLA at 250 again is a distinct possibility.

author: 87th_best_dad
body: A wise friend of mine who championed apple products once told me his secret to indulging in all their products...every time he bought a new apple gizmo he'd buy the same amount in apple stock.
